children.subject: Looks like topics from the description are: Classification regression, clustering, dimensionality, reduction, and density estimation. Mixture models, hierarchical models, factorial models, hidden Markov, and state space models, Markov properties, and recursive algorithms for general probabilistic inference nonparametric methods including decision trees, kernal methods, neural networks, and wavelets. Ensemble methods.
May I know which specific topics will be covered next semester?

Hi, having taken both classes I would say that they are very different. There is some overlapping content in the first few weeks, but they diverge quickly and towards different topics. 110 is not per se necessary for 281A, however the linear algebra experience can’t hurt. However, what you learn in 127 sufficiently covers the necessary linear algebra, uses it in an applied manner, and then studies optimization specifically using these skills. 110 doesn’t (really) cover optimization, whereas that is the sole goal of 127, which is essential for machine learning and hence 189/281A. As such I think 110 is lacking quite a bit in teaching optimization, which it doesn’t really do. Also, I’ve been told by a previous 127 GSI that 110 is a recommended prerequisite (however I took them concurrently and I don’t think 110 was particularly useful or necessary for 127). In a previous post Prof Sahai also recommended 110 if you’re going to grad school, so if you’re interested in that path then either way you should take 110 and 127.
Does Math 110 count as being equivalent to EECS 127?
Could stat 134+150 be used instead of EE 126?

history.content:
We have received several questions about undergraduate enrollment in CS281A. CS281A is a graduate course and is technically not open to undergraduate students. That said, the instructors plan to offer some seats to well-qualified undergraduates. Enrollment priority is for graduate students, and we do not know how many undergraduates will be able to enroll. We expect to not be able to allow undergraduates to enroll until week 3 of the fall semester at the earliest.
If you are interested in this course, you can come to the first day of class to check on the availability of seats. You must have taken EE126, and EE127, and CS189 and received As in all three courses (or appropriate equivalents). There will also be an entrance exam that you will be required to pass in order to gain permission to enroll.
history.subject: undergrad enrollment policy in cs281
